<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Addiction is an important problem at both societal as well as on the personal level. Only recently, addiction has been approach scientifically. Last 15 years there is a major international effort to acquire more knowledge about addiction. Through these international efforts we know a lot more about the mechanisms of addictive behaviors. Where addiction used to be seen as personal weakness, new insights within psychology, psychiatry and neuroscience have now clearly put addiction on the map as a psychological disorder, and not a flaw in the character. About time, because addiction is a disorder that is in the top 3 of most common psychological disorders. Recent developments do not only show there is progress in the theoretical aspect, but also in science-driven and effective treatments.

In this course the gap is bridged between the student and recent scientific insights. Different aspects of addiction will be discussed. Firstly, the background of the problem is described, such as the history, definitions and epidemiology of addiction.
In the second part, several theoretical perspectives are presented, namely the psychological and the neuropsychological models.
In the third part, the focus is on practice of treating addiction and addiction-related problems. Several different treatments are described and diagnostics will be discussed.

In the fourth part, behavioral addictions (such as gambling, game addiction and smoking) will be taught. During this course there is the opportunity to hear guest lecturers from the field (e.g., Bouman GGZ, Rottterdam), including an interview with a patient with an addiction.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

During this course students acquire knowledge about (neuro)psychological theories that explain the development and maintenance of addiction. In addition, knowledge will be gathered on the organisation of addiction care/mental health care in terms of addiction and the content and efficacy of several forms of treatment. Because addiction is a complex disorder and hardly ever is a single disorder, special attention will be paid to comorbidity.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course covers the more challenging and complex issues that analysts, investors, and financial advisors encounter when they evaluate company performance and value firms. We have selected three analytical challenges that will be discussed in more detail:

column2: • Understanding corporate risk management: We will explain the motives for risk management, how risk management is captured in the financial statement and whether risk management makes sense from an investor’s perspective. We will use case studies including Alcatel-Lucent, EADS and Lufthansa.

• Challenges in valuation: We will discuss various complexities in enterprise valuation, such as how to analyse, value, and account for non-equity claims and deal with valuation of conglomerates, private firms and spin-offs.

• Financial analysis and valuation of banks: Our aim is to explain the accounting and valuation for banks. We will discuss the valuation and accounting for banks by using the examples of global banks JP Morgan, HSBC and Goldman Sachs.

column1: <meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students are able to:

column2: • Understand recognition and measurement of banking in financial statements;
• Derive and interpret key performance metrics for banks;
• Apply valuation techniques to banking activities;
• Understand the concept of enterprise value and its different claims;
• Understand, derive and interpret the key metrics to evaluate contingent and fixed claims;
• Apply valuation techniques to contingent and fixed claims;
• Apply analysis and valuation techniques to conglomerates, private firms and spin-offs;
• Understand the different types of risk and motives for risk management;
• Interpret financial statements on risk management and hedge accounting;
• Deal with risk management in forecasting and valuation;
• Discuss and conclude in teams multiple viewpoints on a particular business analysis and valuation case, and present and defend the joint findings in a class setting.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81028,2018,Advanced Economic Evaluation (Eu-HEM),Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. AE Attema', 'dr. SA Lipman', 'prof.dr. H Bleichrodt', 'S Neumann - Boehme, MSc']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course builds on the knowledge acquired during Health Technology Assessment. The focus of the course is more economical than HTA. Several methodological problems in economic evaluation will be treated. The problems treated are typically issues that are at the center of the scientific debate. Students will be encouraged to think actively about these issues and formulate their own opinions in a balanced way.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students should obtain a sound understanding of the methodological difficulties surrounding economic evaluation of health care and their possible solutions. An important aim of the course is to encourage critical reflection on the tools used in economic evaluation of health care.
After completion of this course, the student:

column2: • Is able to formulate their own opinion about methodological problems in economic evaluation in a balanced way.
• Has a sound understanding of the methodological difficulties surrounding economic evaluation.
• Is able to reflect critically on the tools used in economic evaluation of health care.
• Understands the pros and cons of cost-utility analyses and cost-benefit analyses.
• Knows about social welfare theory and the assumptions behind it.
• Understands discounting theory and the assumptions behind it.
• Can explain the relationship between discounting and utility of life duration.
• Can develop their own plan for health utility measurement within economic evaluation.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82183,2018,Advanced Health Economic Modelling,Engels,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['dr. A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. NC Buyukkaramikli', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'dr. WF Thielen', 'H Penton', 'I Corro Ramos, PhD', 'MS Holleman', 'prof.dr. JL Severens']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, such as decision trees and Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses.

This course should help you to get both more theoretical and more practical knowledge on cost-effectiveness modelling. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied, based on Markov modelling. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this. Models will be developed in groups of 3 students, with each week a deadline to hand in the model for review. Two intermediate versions of the model will be assessed through peer-review and one intermediate model and the final model through a formal assessment by staff.
This course is essential for all students who aim to develop a CE-model for their thesis.

The course consists of 10 lectures of 90 minutes, some introducing new material and some that allow interactive feedback on intermediate model versions. In addition, 3 work group meetings of 1.5 hours are planned, and one computer exercise of 3 hours.

The meetings will focus upon: 1) defining the decision problem and describing the disease area, the population, modelling method, perspective, and time horizon ; 2) developing a model structure that reflects the decision problem, progression of the disease, the clinical pathway of treatment, and possible impact of treatment; 3) populating models with disease progression data, effectiveness data of treatment, cost data and data regarding valuation of health states; 4) analysing cost-effectiveness models, performing deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyses and interpreting the results.
The exam is composed of four parts:
•    Final report 40% (20% for introduction to results, group, and 20% conclusion and discussion, individual)
Only the final grade (100%) will be published in Osiris.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>By the end of the course the student is able to:

column2: • set up the framing of an economic evaluation.
• construct, populate and analyse a cost-effectiveness model using a Markov model.
• deliver a report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.
• discuss the strengths and limitations of the modelling approach taken.

A van Dongen - Leunis', 'dr. MJ Al', 'dr. NC Buyukkaramikli', 'dr. P Wetzelaer', 'H Penton', 'I Corro Ramos, PhD', 'prof.dr. JL Severens']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Cost-effectiveness studies aim to evaluate the efficiency of an innovative health technology relative to current care. The basis for such studies are often cost-effectiveness models, based on the principles of health state transition modelling or Markov models. The principles of cost-effectiveness modelling were introduced during previous courses. During this course more advanced applications of cost-effectiveness modelling are being studied and applied. For this purpose, students will work on a real life case developing their own model and writing a technical report to present this.

The course consists of 10 meetings of 90 minutes, which will consist of partly lectures and partly interactive progress reports of the students’ Markov models. In addition 3 work group meetings of 1 hour are planned.

The meetings will focus upon: 1) defining the decision problem and describing the disease area, the population, modelling method, viewpoint, and time horizon ; 2) developing a model structure that reflects the decision problem, progression of the disease, the clinical pathway of treatment, and possible impact of treatment; 3) populating models with disease progression data, effectiveness data of treatment, cost data and data regarding valuation of health states; 4) analysing cost-effectiveness models, performing deterministic and probabilistic sensitivity analyses and interpreting the results.

column2: • It is important for students to have basic knowledge of statistics; students should be familiair with concepts such as the Normal distribution and confidence intervals. This course is only for students from the Eu-HEM programme, and students following the Health Economics specialisation
• Laptop with Excel spreadsheet-software.
• Framing document setting out the boundaries of the decision problem (15% of final grade, individual work)

• Excel spreadsheet on the basis of which cost-effectiveness analyses can be executed, including sensitivity analyses (4 intermediate models at 5% of final grade each plus a final model at 25% of the final grade, group work)

• Study report, describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, technical features and the strengths and limitation of the model developed (40% of final grade, 20% individual work and 20% group work)
• Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

column1: If a student fails the course, the resit will consist of delivering a final model and a final report, each counting as 50% of the final grade. Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

By the end of the course the student is able:

column2: • to construct,  populate and  analyse a cost-effectiveness model based on Markov modelling.
• to deliver a technical report describing the background, principles, structure, inputs, mode of action and technical features of the model developed.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81331,2018,Advanced Qualitative Methods,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. AFM Krijnen', 'dr. I Awad Cherit']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course thoroughly familiarizes students with the theoretical background of qualitative research and its main approaches, including discourse and semiotic analysis, in-depth interviews, focus groups and ethnographic fieldwork, and less traditional methods such as photovoice. It discusses the research process as organic and addresses advantages and disadvantages of the dynamic (and often unpredictable) nature of qualitative research. These discussions are grounded in in-class exercises and close-reading of published research, paying special attention to the flexibility of the analytical frame and the relation between theory and empirical data.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Students will acquire a sound understanding of the theoretical background of qualitative research; they will be able to apply the more commonly used qualitative methods in a sound and creative way and they will be capable of critically evaluating their application by others.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78940,2018,Advanced Quantitative Methods,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. JA Holland'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Advanced Quantitative Methods follows on from Statistics I (1.4). In Statistics I, you were introduced to the role of statistics in social scientific research and you have learned how to use statistical methods to describe quantitative data and test simple explanatory models. In Advanced Quantitative Methods, we will build upon this knowledge, going deeper into inferential techniques to test social scientific hypotheses and expanding your quantitative methods toolkit. In particular we will develop your knowledge of three analytical techniques: reliability analysis, multiple regression analysis, and logistic regression analysis. You will apply these techniques to a range of national and international data sources in order to answer real-world, social scientific research questions. You will be introduced to these methods in lecture sessions. You will deepen your understanding with hands-on practice in weekly computer practical and tutorial sessions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Having completed this course, you will be able to:

column2: • Demonstrate interrelationships between variables and operationalize social science concepts using factor analysis;
• Assess the reliability of quantitative measures of social science concepts;
• Develop, draw and interpret conceptual models to explore and explain mediating, moderating, suppression and spurious relationships between variables;
• Apply multiple linear and logistic regression analysis to understand the relationships between variables and test conceptual models;
• Interpret the results of statistical analysis and report these results in a clear way;
• Explain the assumptions underlie multiple regression analysis and (to the extent possible) to check whether they are violated.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81330,2018,Advanced Quantitative Methods,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['prof.dr. MNM Verboord', 'prof.dr. W de Koster']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course provides an overview and understanding of the more commonly used and applied multivariate, statistical techniques and the skills to design, carry out and judge sophisticated, quantitative research projects. Specifically, the course covers statistical techniques needed for data reduction (scale and factor analysis), cross-sectional analyses (multiple linear and logistic regression analysis, path analysis) and for comparative analysis (time-series analysis, multilevel and meta-analysis). The course is 'advanced' in terms of concepts and methods, rather than statistical theory or mathematics. The focus is on real-world applications, discussing the assumptions, limitations and interpretations of a wide range of statistical techniques.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students will understand key concepts and assumptions in the more commonly used quantitative methods, including advanced statistical methods for complex data; they will be able to use these methods in a sound and creative way, and they will be able to critically assess their application by other researchers.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83770,2018,Advanced R,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. A Alfons', 'dr. PC Schoonees']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The open-source software environment R (www.R-project.org) is a powerful platform for data analysis and statistical graphics that has become the global standard in statistical computing. R houses an ever-growing extensive collection of tools for statistics and data analysis – an attractive basis for thorough exploration of your data. Furthermore, it provides a powerful programming language coupled with flexible graphical capabilities.

This follow-up to the introductory course will focus on programming in R. Basic programming concepts will be covered, such as accessing and altering parts of objects, controlling the order of computations, iteratively performing tasks using loops, and writing functions. We will also take a look at functional programming, and how to use these tools in practice. For example, and time permitting, it will be illustrated how these tools can be utilized when using R to scrape data from the web.
Upon completion of the course, you will be able to use the power of R’s programming language for advanced analytic tasks to improve the quality of your research.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
IMPORTANT: Students without a background in quantitative and qualitative research methods are strongly advised to follow the preparatory e-learning modules that are offered by ESHPM.

This master’s course is obligatory for HEPL and HCM/ZoMa students. The aim is to enhance students’ quantitative and qualitative research skills, which can later be applied in subsequent courses and in writing the master thesis. The course builds on students’ existing knowledge of statistics and qualitative research methods.
Workgroup sessions are the core of the course. This is where concepts and methods are put into practice after they have been introduced in lectures and literature.

The focus is not on learning many new (statistical) methods – since a solid knowledge of those is assumed beforehand - but mostly on interpreting and criticizing results, combining theory and data, and seeing the big picture. A key element of the course is assessing the design and execution of existing successful and flawed studies.

The course consists of two parts. In the first three weeks, quantitative and epidemiological topics will be the focus. They include causal inference, using causal graphs as a tool for designing quantitative analyses, and advanced interpretation of logistic and ordinary least squared regression results. The next two weeks will be devoted to understanding qualitative research methods, with a specific focus on formulating theoretically informed research questions, searching for and synthesising literature and combining qualitative methodologies with other methodologies. In the final week, quantitative and qualitative methods will be combined and students will present their assessments of several published studies.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
This master’s course is obligatory for HCM/ZoMa students.
The aim is to enhance students’ quantitative and qualitative research skills, which can later be applied in subsequent courses and in writing the master thesis.

column2: • to evaluate the quality of quantitative and qualitative studies
• to explain the role of causal theories in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed understanding of the concepts of statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
• to use theory in ethnographic research and the study of organizational practices
• to recognize different forms of discourse analysis and perform a basic discourse analysis
• to construct qualitative research questions from existing literature
• to recognize the advantages and disadvantages of digital and multi-sited ethnography in healthcare research
• to understand the differences between gap spotting and problematisation when constructing qualitative research questions
• To develop a view on the potential contributions of quantitative and qualitative methods to science in general and to answering specific research questions

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
The aim of this course is to enhance students’ quantitative and qualitative research skills, which can later be applied in subsequent courses and in writing the master thesis.

column2: • to evaluate the quality of quantitative and qualitative studies
• to explain the role of causal theories in the design and interpretation of quantitative studies
• to apply directed acyclic graphs and casual theory in the design and interpretation of an analysis
• to translate the results of linear and logistic regression into meaningful causal and associational concepts that apply to specific research questions
• to apply a well-developed understanding of the concepts of statistical significance and effect size in the interpretation of study results
• to use theory in ethnographic research and the study of organizational practices
• to recognize different forms of discourse analysis and perform a basic discourse analysis
• to construct qualitative research questions from existing literature
• to recognize the advantages and disadvantages of digital and multi-sited ethnography in healthcare research
• to understand the differences between gap spotting and problematisation when constructing qualitative research questions
• To develop a view on the potential contributions of quantitative and qualitative methods to science in general and to answering specific research questions

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81105,2018,Advanced Sociology of Arts and Culture,Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['dr. TJ Hoebink'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The sociology of arts and culture has rapidly developed over the last decades. It is seen as one of the most promising subfields of sociology. Its insights have influenced the policy, practice and reception of the arts. More and more attention is given to the context in which arts and culture are produced and consumed. Taken for granted meanings and statuses have been problematized, myths have been debunked, and previously ignored forms of art and culture are now taken seriously.

However, as the sociology of arts and culture is such a dynamic field, debates are still ongoing and developing.  The purpose of this course is to bring you up to date with the latest developments in this field and to make you acquainted with the most current subjects of dispute. For this we’ll draw on the research experience that is available at the ESHCC. Through a series of guest lectures, staff members of the ESHCC will introduce you to their own research practice, and explain how their research ties into international academic debates. The subjects range from post-distinction (is there life after Bourdieu?) to new experimental research methods and techniques (what lies beyond the survey?).

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The aim of this course is to offer an overview of recent topics and developments in sociology of arts and culture. We will invite a number of guest lecturers, mostly from within our department.Each week we’ll discuss one theoretical and one empirical text, on which you’ll write short reading notes. The final assignment consists of a literature study that explores the current academic debate on one of the course themes in greater detail.</body>

FH Wijen', 'prof.dr. HW Volberda', 'prof.dr. JJP Jansen', 'prof.dr. TH Reus', 'prof.dr. TJM Mom']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This intensive course will cover state-of-the-art research in a variety of strategic management topics, including corporate venturing, strategic collaboration, scaling up, and institutional relations. During a week of intensive interactions on campus, you will discover, present, and discuss recent and landmark publications around strategic capita selecta. You will peruse several important publications around a particular topic prior to the course, analyze the academic strengths and limitations of different readings, discuss their adopted approach and practical relevance with fellow PhD candidates and seasoned researchers, and write a paper on an “engaged strategy” topic of your choice.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>The course has three major aims. First, you will become cognizant of a series of prominent academic articles covering several subfields of strategic management. Second, you will discover “engaged strategizing,” that is, applying academic insights around the strategic opportunities and limitations of business in addressing real-world societal challenges. Third, you will come to grips with the epistemological and contextual specificities of performing engaged research.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>We will start by consolidating and deepening the DCF approach through a few selected topics: careful, correct calculation of cash flows and alternative approaches (comparable companies, alternative income/cash flow approaches) and the conditions for the equivalence between some of those. Next we will move to the core part of the course: to extend those valuation techniques to banks and other financial institutions, since these require variations of and adjustments to the standard techniques due to their particular characteristics. In doing so we will analyse the business model of financial companies and pay attention to the particular importance that a good understanding of their annual accounts has. We will close the course with some thoughts on managing for value – why companies should be managed for value and what managing for value means. Throughout the course we will pay some attention to how one can present ideas a variety of charts. Students will apply all these techniques to a company of their choice.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>This course provides a solid knowledge of the techniques available for valuing companies. In this respect, the learning objectives are:

column2: • To consolidate the basic DCF approach and to take this knowledge one level deeper;
• To understand and be able to challenge its theoretical foundations;
• To understand how DCF and alternative income approaches (economic profit, residual earnings) are related, their advantages and disadvantages, as well as the use of multiples;
• To understand the business model of banks and financial institutions and to learn how to value these companies;
• What value creation is, how companies create and destroy value, and how value creation can be measured?
• To argue why companies should or should not be managed for value;
• To analyse a company’s strategy and business model from a value creating perspective and to present conclusions.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Consumers encounter communications about brands anytime and anywhere: While commuting – via billboards, posters, mobile devices or on the car radio; in the office – reading business newspapers, browsing on websites or when opening direct mail; at home – watching TV, listening to the radio, interacting with tablets or handling packages; while attending sports events, concerts and movies – on tickets, in the program brochure, on the field, on the screen, on clothing. Marketing managers require useful frameworks to effectively communicate and advertise their products and services.

This course discusses all aspects involved in designing effective marketing communications campaigns. The purpose of the course is to get introduced to the major topics in marketing communications and to further develop your communication skills through written projects, team-based work, and oral presentations.

The goal of this course is to help students set marketing communications objectives for a variety of products/services; understand and apply the principles that are necessary for persuasive advertising, from strategic principles (information, influence, emotion and mere exposure) to more specific tactics (resistance, acceptance, message, attention); generate, select and evaluate creative ideas for an advertising campaign; set a campaign budget and select appropriate media (still/motion) for a marketing communications campaign, taking into account strategic and tactical rules for implementation of the media plan; and propose/design an advertising campaign and discuss, present and defend the proposed campaign.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
At the end of this course students will be able to:

column2: <li>
recognize, understand and explain the principles behind effective marketing communication
<li>
analyze and evaluate existing marketing communications by identifying their strengths and weaknesses
<li>
create and develop an effective marketing campaign

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Veel ouders hebben vragen over de opvoeding van hun kind. Meestal gaan deze vragen over huilen, slapen, eten, zindelijkheid, straffen en belonen, en pesten. Er bestaan vele soorten opvoedadvies, maar hoe werkt dat in de praktijk? Hoe adviseer je ouders en opvoeders over hun opvoedvragen? En welk wetenschappelijk onderbouwd opvoedadvies is er voorhanden? De focus tijdens dit blok ligt op de vroege erkenning van opvoedproblemen, van de babytijd tot aan de adolescentie. Er zijn voor ouders heel veel boeken en websites beschikbaar, maar welk daarvan zijn wetenschappelijk onderbouwd? Om dit te bestuderen ga je tijdens dit blok verschillende populaire opvoedboeken en andere media screenen, en gastdocenten uit het werkveld van opvoedadvies (zoals het Centrum voor Jeugd en Gezin) zullen vertellen over de laatste stand van zaken. Het practicum 'Schrijven van een opvoedbrochure/opvoedwebsite' loopt gelijk met het blok. In het practicum ontwerp je een opvoedbrochure, gebaseerd op de wetenschappelijke bevindingen uit het blok. Tijdens het practicum bestudeer je de wetenschappelijke onderbouwing van verschillende soorten opvoedadvies uit populaire opvoedboeken en andere media. De wetenschappelijke onderzoeken vertaal je in bruikbaar advies aan ouders in een opvoedbrochure of opvoedwebsite inclusief wetenschappelijke onderbouwing.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column2: • Opvoedproblemen van de babytijd tot de adolescentie te identificeren;
• De theorie en praktijk van opvoedadvies te evalueren;
• Kritisch te reflecteren op de wetenschappelijke en praktische waarde van opvoedadvies, en dit te presenteren aan professionals, opvoeders en ouders;
• Een brochure of website te maken met wetenschappelijk onderbouwd opvoedadvies.

column4: Dit practicum biedt studenten een eerste kennismaking met de praktijk van het schrijven van een beleidsadvies. Studenten zullen eerst leren over de betekenis van beleid voor jongeren en andere actoren in de stedelijke context. Vervolgens gaan studenten in een Rotterdams beleidsstuk over jeugdcriminaliteit op zoek naar de problemen die de gemeente wil aanpakken, de doelen die de gemeente nastreeft en de middelen die de gemeente inzet om de doelen te bereiken. Studenten leren de (soms impliciete) veronderstellingen in het beleidsstuk te analyseren en op basis van theoretische en empirische inzichten hier kritisch op te reflecteren.

column2: </body>

column4: En een inhoudelijke evaluatie van een concreet beleidsstuk op het terrein van de jeugdcriminaliteit te schrijven en te presenteren, waarbij ze met beperkte instructie en begeleiding:

column5: een afgebakende pedagogische of onderwijskundige onderzoeksvraag formuleren (eindterm 9);

verbanden leggen tussen bronnen, informatie uit verschillende bronnen integreren, tegenstrijdigheden, ontbrekende informatie en inconsistenties identificeren en bronnen kritisch beschouwen (eindterm 13);
een samenhangende en heldere tekst schrijven (eindterm 15);
een wetenschappelijke schrijfstijl toepassen (eindterm 15);
een wetenschappelijke tekst schrijven met de geëigende structuurindeling (eindterm 15);
zowel in tekst als in de literatuurlijst refereren op basis van de normen van de American Psychological Association (APA) voor het gebruik van- en verwijzen naar bronnen (eindterm 15);
op een heldere en sluitende wijze schriftelijk argumenteren (eindterm 15);
feedback over hun werk vragen, ontvangen en op adequate wijze kunnen verwerken (eindterm 19).

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80201,2018,Advisory Skills,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AJJA Maas', 'dr. MJ Flory']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

The list of skills necessary for working in any organisational environment is long. In this course, we will use the method of process consultation to pay attention to how people can advise.  This will result in increased communication, advisory and coaching skills.

This course focuses on how students communicate and react to other people in different contexts. The course is designed to enable the students to build and develop their advisory skills and to increase knowledge of the concepts behind them, so as to widen the choice of possible actions in a given situation and to develop the understanding of the strengths and weakness of their advisory skills. By the end of the course we will have provided the students with an opportunity to learn about and practice by understanding and diagnosing contexts and give advice. Guests, consultants, trainers and managers can also provide lectures.

This elective is built up around lectures and workshops provided by the teacher and around 6-8 workshops (provided by the students). The sessions consist of experiential learning, theory, group exercises, and individual exercises and are provided by the lecturer, a consultant, or the teams themselves. During these sessions, we will explore various consultancy skills like questioning, analysing situations, problem sensing versus problem solution, relation building, handling intake process, teambuilding, et cetera.
The advisory skills course is all about skills; it is not something you can learn from a book. Therefore, the general rule is that you are present at all sessions.
For the workshops, the teams are likely to be divided into two groups, A and B. You and your team only have to be present during the session where a team in your group is giving the workshop.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

column2: <li>
Enable students to discuss and articulate their own views on consultancy
<li>
Support students to reflect on and develop their own skills
<li>
Enable students to practice with experiential learning
<li>
Enable students to distinguish and practice with different roles of consulting

column1: After the course students are able to:

column2: <li>
Know more about and have experiences with experiential learning
<li>
Know what the essential advisory skills are and have practiced these
<li>
Have increased knowledge of concepts and know the differences between different advisory concepts
<li>
Develop a training session on one particular advisory skill.
<li>
Develop more communication skills

column1: Develop a better understanding of the strength and weaknesses of own possibilities as change agent
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81064,2018,Aesthetics,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. FDR Maet', 'dr. N van Poecke']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Particularly since the start of the 18th century, philosophers began to reflect on the question of art resulting in the emergence of ‘aesthetics’ as an independent philosophical discipline. This has resulted in the formation of various theories of and perspectives on the nature of art – from the theory of mimesis to expression theories; from formalism to post-structuralism, and beyond. The emergence of these perspectives are linked with the role of art in society and culture and, moreover, influence the criteria under which art is created, produced and consumed. In contemporary (western) societies questions on the status and legitimation of the arts are even more pressing. In this course, various philosophers and their aesthetic theories will be discussed – e.g. Plato, Aristotle, Baudrillard, Derrida, Kant, Hegel and Nietzsche – as well as that their theories will be illustrated with reference to examples from art history. Amongst other examples, Nietzsche’s theory of the ‘tragic in art’ will be explained in the context of pre-war American blues music, and Hegel’s and Danto’s theory on the ‘end of art’ will be illustrated with examples ranging from contemporary (conceptual) art and pop culture, such as Duchamp’s urinal and Lana del Rey.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>Students will be acquainted with theories and concepts from the field of aesthetics. Following a thematic and historical overview of aesthetic theory they will familiarize themselves with various philosophical perspectives on the question ‘What is art?’. Though the course focuses on Western aesthetic theory, students are encouraged to take a comparative perspective on the study of art, art history, aesthetics and the art world.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81828,2018,Aesthetics,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['dr. S van Tuinen'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This module offers an introduction to a diversity of philosophical perspectives on art. Besides theclassical points of view of Plato, Aristoteles, Kant, Hegel and Nietzsche, we will focus on 20<sup>th</sup> century philosophers: Lukacs, Adorno, Benjamin, Jameson, Baudrillard, Lyotard, Derrida, Merleau-Ponty, Deleuze, Badiou and Ranciere. Contrary to philosophy’s traditional derogatory treatment of art, these philosophers have elaborated a new complicity between art and philosophy. Instead of speaking about art, they have started a dialogue between art and philosophy that in some cases even culminates in an aestheticization of thought and a self-reflective turn towards the artificiality of philosophy. The course is organized around three thematic clusters: 1) art and truth; 2) Marxist cultural critique; 3) modernist philosophies of art.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
To acquire a global overview of the philosophical sub-discipline of Aesthetics, of its history and development, and of its contemporary relevance;
To acquire a limited but relevant toolbox for a critical attitude towards art and its changing socio-political significance;
To learn about various ways in which art and philosophy have come to interfere in the course of the 20<sup>th</sup> century.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80369,2018,Aesthetics & Politics: A Genealogy of Social Order,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['dr. CDC van der Veeke'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Aesthetics & Politics provides an exciting journey through the landscape of art and politics, showing both the main views and some more intricate hidden aspects of their interrelationship. Based on cutting-edge thought about the status of philosophy and art in history, the course outlines several ‘regimes of perception’ that structure the way we perceive the world, think about it, act in it, and judge it. We will see how this is manifested in and expressed by famous works of philosophy, as well as in art works in diverse fields, such as music, painting, literature and theatre. We aim to convey that society and its representations in art and philosophy are neither neutral nor self-evident, but always figure within political and aesthetic frameworks that determine what is visible and what is not, what counts and what does not.

The intimate relation between art and politics is sometimes manifest but often remains latent. One might even feel that there should be no connection at all between art and politics – and that this independence is a precondition for the existence of art. As the course will show, this view expresses a specifically modern attitude towards art and politics. And in a way, it is exactly this ‘freedom’ from determination by institutions or power that makes art, in a new and typically modern way, ‘political’.

For these and many more reasons, it is important to clarify the sometimes confusing but always intricate and multifaceted relation between art and politics, as it has determined Western history and culture. This long story begins millennia ago with the start of Western philosophy, back in the days of Homer, Socrates, Plato and Aristotle, and the tragedians Sophocles and Euripides. The way they make the world visible and influence our experience of it has had a decisive influence on Western culture – on the relationships between poetry, music, painting, crafts and philosophy. The second half of the course will focus on these elements of art and culture from the Renaissance to modernity, showing how they are related to politics and society. We will see how a wide range of artistic forms and practices give expression to new notions of freedom and politics.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
After completing the course, students will be able to:

column2: • Elaborate on the interrelationship between art theory and political theory, and by implication the role of aesthetics in politics, as well as politics in different periods of artistic expression;
• Describe and explain the role of art and the artist in relation to epic poetry in the Greek polis as conceptualised by Plato in The Republic and, by extension, the role of art for Plato in general;
• Describe and explain the ways in which the performance and reception of tragedy are related to philosophy, art and social hierarchy according to Aristotle;

• Describe and explain the role of carnival in the late Middle Ages, as well as the way in which the Renaissance meant both a break with and a continuation of the way art and the artist were perceived in the Middle Ages.

• Describe and explain the aesthetic philosophy of Schiller as presented in his Letters on the Aesthetic Education of Man, by focusing on the notion of 'free play' and the emancipatory implications of his concept of, and role for, art; and how the emancipatory (Schillerian) ideals are expressed in Hugo's Les Misérables;

• Describe and explain the ways in which Nietzsche's early writings on tragedy, and the music and writings of Wagner, express key aspects of the modern romantic experience of aesthetics, politics, and freedom; and
• Describe and explain Rancière’s notion of a ‘regime of art’: what does it say about the relation between philosophy, politics, and art?

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/78957,2018,Afstemming binnen Opvoeding en Onderwijs,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. MHF Deutz'],,Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De ontwikkeling van het kind vormt de basis van het werk van pedagogen. Volgens het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner vindt de ontwikkeling van het kind plaats door interacties tussen het kind en diens omgeving. In het blok ‘Afstemming binnen opvoeding en onderwijs’ richten we ons vooral op de onmiddellijke omgeving waarin het kind zich begeeft, zoals het gezin en de school. De complexe relatie tussen opvoeden en onderwijzen, en de mogelijke invloed van de al dan niet succesvolle afstemming binnen opvoeding en onderwijs op de ontwikkeling van kinderen, komt daarbij aan de orde. Theorie wordt afgewisseld met praktische voorbeelden (zoals het ontbreken van mannelijke leerkrachten in het basisonderwijs, opgesloten zitten in een jeugdinstelling en de maatschappelijke opdracht van het onderwijs) om het belang aan te tonen van de ‘fit’ tussen opvoedingssituaties en onderwijs.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column4: Aan het einde van dit blok zijn studenten in staat om:

column5: het ecologische model van Bronfenbrenner te beschrijven en de onderwerpen uit het blok binnen het model te plaatsen (eindterm 1);

de invloed van proximale processen in twee belangrijke microsystemen (gezin en peers) en de relatie tussen deze microsystemen (mesoniveau) en probleemgedrag van jongeren in hun thuissituatie en in de jeugdzorg te beschrijven (eindterm 5);
de samenhang tussen leer- en ontwikkelingsproblemen te beschrijven en toe te passen op diagnose en behandeling in de onderwijscontext (eindtermen 4, 5 en 7);

een wetenschappelijk onderbouwde mening te vormen over de afstemming tussen twee belangrijke microsystemen (ouders en school) in het bereiken van leerprestaties en het bijbrengen van normen en waarden (eindtermen 3 en 14);
de invloed van het uitstellen van volwassenheid te beschrijven op de verschuiving in microsystemen door de jaren heen (eindterm 4).

column2: </body>

column3: Vanaf blok 2 wordt in groepjes van vijf studenten begonnen met het formuleren van de probleemstelling en de onderzoeksvragen voor het Afstudeerproject, alsmede met het ontwikkelen een theoretisch en methodisch kader.

Het afstudeerproject is verdeeld over drie vakken en begint met ‘Onderzoeksopzet’ (blok 2), vervolgens het vak ‘Dataverzameling en –analyse’ (blok 3) en tot slot het vak ‘De Masterscriptie’ (blok 4 en blok 5).

Het afstudeerproject wordt afgerond met de masterscriptie Criminologie. Een succesvolle afronding van het afstudeerproject levert 20 ECTS op. De zojuist genoemde vakken in blok 2 en blok 3 van het afstudeerproject worden niet met een cijfer beoordeeld, maar moeten als voldoende worden beoordeeld door de begeleidende docent om aan het volgende blok deel te kunnen nemen.
In blok 5 worden de data voor het Afstudeerproject verzameld en geanalyseerd en wordt de scriptie geschreven (15 ects van in totaal 20 ects).</body>

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80513,2018,Afstudeerproject/Scriptie Master Bestuurskunde,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. PK Marks'],,Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Als afronding van het masterprogramma doen studenten een afstudeerproject. Hierin staat toepassing van verworven inzicht, kennis en competenties centraal. Het is dan ook met recht de meesterproef.

In het kader van het afstudeerproject schrijven studenten individueel een scriptie. De aard van het eindproduct kan verschillend zijn, afhankelijk van de aard van de opdracht. Het kan bijvoorbeeld gaan om een onderzoeksrapport, een meer theoretische verkenning, een organisatiediagnose en -advies, een beleidsontwerp, een implementatieplan, of een beleidsevaluatie. Steeds zal echter gebruik gemaakt moeten worden theoretische inzichten, wetenschappelijke methoden en reflectie op academisch niveau.

Het afstudeertraject wordt begeleid door een afstudeerdocent. Dat gebeurt in zogenaamde afstudeerkringen die gevormd worden rondom vier enigermate verwante afstudeerprojecten. Daarnaast is de module Wetenschapspracticum II specifiek op ondersteuning van het afstudeertraject gericht.

In de startbijeenkomst van het masterjaar wordt een toelichting op het afstudeertraject en de daarin te zetten stappen gegeven. Daarbij wordt op algemene methodische aspecten ingegaan. Specifiek zal in deze bijeenkomst ingegaan worden op de probleemstelling, gebruik van theorie en operationalisering. Een aantal avonden in het kader van Wetenschapspracticum II gaat over methode van dataverzameling, causaal redeneren en het doen van wetenschappelijk onderbouwde uitspraken. Na de tweede inhoudelijke module is er twee weken voor het afstudeerproject beschikbaar. In de afstudeerkringen worden de onderzoeksopzetten en de (aanzetten tot) een theoretisch kader van de afstudeerprojecten besproken. Na de derde inhoudelijke module (eind maart) is er opnieuw tijd voor het afstudeerproject. In de scriptiekringen komen uitgewerkte theoretische kaders en operationalisering aan de orde. Ook kunnen eerste empirische verkenningen worden besproken. Vanaf medio mei wordt het afstudeerproject afgerond. In de scriptiekringen wordt aandacht besteed aan het interpreteren van verzamelde empirische informatie en het trekken van gefundeerde conclusies. Er kunnen nog scriptiekringbijeenkomsten worden gepland. Eind juni worden de voorlopige resultaten gepresenteerd. Om in september af te studeren dienen de definitieve, goedgekeurde scripties medio augustus beschikbaar te zijn.
Elk eindproduct dient te voldoen aan de volgende criteria:<ul>

column1: • heldere probleemstelling met uiteindelijk een helder antwoord;
• een helder, goed leesbaar, en dus goed geschreven document met een duidelijke opbouw;
• gedegen, kritisch en creatief gebruik van relevante (bestuurskundige) theorieën;
• wetenschappelijke onderbouwing bevindingen, en goed onderbouwde oordelen, adviezen en conclusies.

Bij de beoordeling speelt de originaliteit en het academische niveau een belangrijke rol, maar ook het oordeel van de opdrachtgever over de bruikbaarheid van het product. De beoordeling van de verdediging weegt mee in het eindcijfer.
• op basis daarvan formuleren van wetenschappelijk onderbouwde diagnoses, conclusies en adviezen;
• kunnen verbinden van en reflecteren op theorie en praktijk.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80518,2018,Afstudeertraject Master Beleid en Politiek,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. PL Hupe', 'prof.dr. HJM Fenger', 'prof.dr. MW van Buuren', 'prof.dr. VJJM Bekkers']",,"Inhoud

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: De Master Beleid en Politiek dient afgerond te worden met een Masterscriptie, die wetenschappelijk verantwoord dient te zijn. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient op een transparante en navolgbare te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Masterscriptie aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (inleiding met probleemstelling, werkwijze, theoretisch kader, empirische analyse, resultaten, conclusie, reflectie) duidelijke vormgeving, correcte bronvermelding e.d. (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie). De docenten van de Master geven tevoren hun onderwerpen van expertise en belangstelling aan (zie tabblad afstudeerdocenten). Daaruit kunnen studenten kiezen. Het staat studenten overigens vrij om zelf met onderwerpen te komen. Studenten kunnen eventueel gezamenlijk een Masterscriptie schrijven. Daarbij gaat het dan wel om een groepje van twee personen. De individuele bijdrage moet echter wel herkenbaar en toetsbaar zijn, aangezien de eindbeoordeling individueel plaats vindt. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject. Student en docent stellen daartoe een 'contract' op met rechten en plichten voor beide partijen.

In het afstudeertraject zijn methodische seminars voorzien die gezamenlijk door alle studenten van de Master verplicht worden gevolgd. Aan de hand van concrete voorbeelden van bestaande onderzoeken zullen de studenten in groepsverband getraind worden in het doen van onderzoek. Daarbij zal het accent vooral komen te liggen op a) het werken met een probleemstelling, c) het werken met een conceptueel model, c) op het operationaliseren en meetbaar maken van centrale begrippen en d) het formuleren van wetenschappelijk gefundeerde en praktisch bruikbare aanbevelingen.

Omdat studenten een verplichte stage moeten lopen, is het raadzaam om in het eerste blok een stageplek te verwerven. In blokken drie en/of vier dient er een stage gelopen te worden en tegelijkertijd gewerkt te worden aan de scriptie. In het vierde blok wordt de Masterscriptie afgerond. Aan het begin van onderwijsblok 3 dient een definitieve opzet van de afstudeerscriptie gemaakt te worden. Iedere student beschrijft op één A4 de eerste globale opzet van de scriptie:

column5: aanleiding en doelstelling voor het afstudeer onderzoek;
probleemstelling, nader onderverdeeld in deelvragen;
opzet en wijze van aanpak, onderzoeksmethode;
theoretische invalshoek, literatuur;
empirische analyse, informatieverzameling;
concept hoofdstuk indeling.

column3: Studenten worden in blok 3 aan de hand van hun voorstel ingedeeld in scriptiekringen die worden begeleid door een docent van de opleiding bestuurskunde. Een kring bestaat doorgaans uit 3 tot 5 personen. Meestal gaat het om scripties die een zekere verwantschap met elkaar hebben. Deze kringen komen periodiek bij elkaar. In de kring worden de vorderingen tot dan toe besproken, waarbij studenten over en weer verplicht elkaars stukken lezen en daarop ook commentaar leveren. De bedoeling is dat op deze manier leerkringen ontstaan, waar studenten elkaars ervaringen en problemen met elkaar kunnen delen. Doorgaans gaat het om ervaringen waarmee een ieder tegelijkertijd wordt geconfronteerd. Deelname aan de scriptiekringen, het tijdig uitwisselen van elkaar stukken en actieve deelname zijn verplicht.</body>

column1: Na afloop van deze module kan de student:
• zelfstandig een relevante probleemstelling formuleren voor een praktijkgericht wetenschappelijk onderzoek;
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• verschillende empirische bevindingen koppelen aan theoretische concepten;
• zelfstandig (een) wetenschappelijk gefundeerde conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• persoonlijke reflectie geven ten aanzien van het eigen onderzoek;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80530,2018,Afstudeertraject Master Management HR & Verandering,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Social and Behavioural Sciences,,['dr. B Vermeeren', 'dr. NJL Cannaerts', 'prof.dr. AJ Steijn', 'prof.dr. L den Dulk']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De Master Management van HR en Verandering wordt afgerond met een master thesis. In deze thesis laat de student zien in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen uitwerken en onderzoeken. De thesis of scriptie is dan ook van wetenschappelijk niveau en wordt zodanig verantwoord. Dit betekent dat wetenschappelijke literatuur wordt verwerkt, wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten worden toegepast, empirisch materiaal op verantwoorde wijze wordt verzameld en geanalyseerd en reflectie plaatsvindt op de bestuurskundige theorie en praktijk. Verder dient de Master thesis aan de gebruikelijke vereisten te voldoen, zoals een heldere en systematische opbouw (zie Handleiding Masterscriptie).

De onderwerpkeuze wordt getoetst aan de bestuurskundige relevantie waar het het studiegebied van management van HR en verandering betreft. Studenten kiezen een thema, gekoppeld aan een afstudeerkring en afstudeerbegeleider. Tijdens het verloop van het afstudeeronderzoek zullen groepjes studenten rond een gekozen thema in de afstudeerkring regelmatig met de afstudeerbegeleider bijeenkomen om de onderzoeksvoortgang en tussentijdse producten met elkaar te bespreken en verder te ontwikkelen. Gedurende het afstudeertraject worden tussen de student en de begeleidend docent afspraken gemaakt over de te volgen werkwijze, de fasen in het project, deadlines en op te leveren deelproducten in het afstudeertraject.

Aanvullend op het afstudeertraject worden de verplichte seminars van het Atelier MHVR en de seminars over methoden en technieken gevolgd (zie hiervoor de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De seminars over methoden en technieken volgen daarbij in de tijd de opbouw van het afstudeeronderzoek zodat het afstudeertraject zo veel als mogelijk wordt ondersteund. Het afstudeertraject omvat tevens een stage (zie hiervoor opnieuw de desbetreffende studiegidstekst). De verwerving van een stageplaats vindt hoofdzakelijk in het tweede blok plaats. Ook hierbij is het Atelier ondersteunend. Studenten lopen stage in blok 3 en blok 4 en werken gelijktijdig aan de scriptie.</body>
• zelfstandig wetenschappelijke literatuur gebruiken om een theoretisch kader te ontwikkelen en om empirisch materiaal op een verantwoorde wijze te analyseren;
• zelfstandig een methodologische verantwoording geven van de keuzes in het onderzoek;
• zelfstandig (een) conclusie(s) formuleren in aansluiting op de vraagstelling;
• zelfstandig aanbevelingen formuleren op basis van empirische bevindingen en theoretische aspecten;
• zelfstandig een onderzoeksrapportage schriftelijk presenteren volgens wetenschappelijke standaarden.

column2: <head><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>

column3: Met een masterthesis (scriptie) wordt de studie afgerond. De thesis vormt het bewijs van vakbekwaamheid bij het integreren van kennis. De student toont aan in staat te zijn een bestuurskundige probleemstelling op academisch niveau te kunnen onderzoeken en daarover op een heldere wijze te rapporteren.

De masterthesis dient wetenschappelijk verantwoord te zijn. Ofschoon organisatieontwerp of -advies wel onderwerp van afstuderen kan zijn, is kritiekloos toepassen van een bestaand 'model' niet voldoende. Er dient sprake te zijn van het gebruik van wetenschappelijke literatuur, van de toepassing van wetenschappelijke bestuurskundige kennis en inzichten, het empirisch materiaal dient verantwoord te zijn geanalyseerd, en bovenal dient sprake te zijn van wetenschappelijke reflectie op theorie en praktijk.

In de eerste helft van het jaar worden probleemstelling, opzet en werkwijze gereed gemaakt. Vervolgens wordt gewerkt aan de definitieve opzet van de thesis en vindt bestudering van relevante theoretische literatuur plaats. In het derde blok vindt, gekoppeld aan de stage, de verzameling van empirisch materiaal plaats. In het vierde blok volgt de analyse en wordt de masterthesis afgerond.

Het afstudeertraject wordt in seminars ondersteund. Deze seminars zijn opgenomen in het atelierprogramma. Het afstudeertraject heeft een omvang van 15 ECTS, ongeveer drie maanden werktijd en sluit zo goed mogelijk aan op de stage (10 ECTS), die kan worden gebruikt voor de verzameling van empirisch materiaal. Studenten die stage en scriptie combineren - wat meestal zo is - zijn gemiddeld 4-6 maanden bezig met het afstudeertraject. In het atelier zal aan het begin van blok 2 aandacht worden besteed aan het zoeken van een stageplaats en aan de eisen die er aan een stageplaats moeten worden gesteld.

Studenten schrijven in principe individueel een masterthesis. Er worden afstudeerkringen gevormd van meerdere studenten die verwante afstudeerprojecten doen. Elke afstudeerkring wordt begeleid door een docent.</mystyle></body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82592,2018,Algemene economie,Nederlands,Erasmus School of Health Policy & Management,,"['drs. SA van der Geest', 'prof.dr. FT Schut', 'prof.dr. M Varkevisser']",,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

De gezondheidszorg wordt in toenemende mate geconfronteerd met schaarste. Een centraal onderwerp binnen de economische wetenschap betreft het doelmatig gebruik van schaarse middelen. De toenemende aandacht van economen voor gezondheidszorg kan dan ook deels worden verklaard door het feit dat de sector gezondheidszorg in de afgelopen decennia een steeds groter beslag is gaan leggen op de schaarse nationale middelen. Gelet op de demografische en technologische ontwikkelingen zal de vraag naar gezondheidszorg eerder toe- dan afnemen.

Om de gezondheidszorg ook op langere termijn voor iedereen betaalbaar te houden is het van belang dat met de beschikbare middelen zo doelmatig mogelijk wordt omgesprongen. Bij ""normale"" goederen en diensten kan “de markt” (lees: concurrentie) prikkels voor een doelmatig gebruik van middelen geven. Maar de gezondheidszorg heeft een aantal specifieke kenmerken waardoor een vrije markt vaak niet goed kan werken.

In het vak Algemene Economie van de Gezondheidszorg (AEG) wordt kennis gemaakt met (i) de grondbeginselen van zowel de klassieke micro-economie als de institutionele economie en (ii) de specifieke toepassing daarvan op de gezondheidszorg. Bijzondere aandacht wordt besteed aan de vraag naar en de productie van gezondheid, de voor- en nadelen van ziektekostenverzekeringen en de oorzaken en gevolgen van markt- en overheidsfalen in de gezondheidszorg.
De leerstof wordt besproken en uitgelegd in hoorcolleges, terwijl in werkgroepen wordt geoefend met toepassingen op concrete vraagstukken.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>Op vakniveau worden de volgende leerdoelen nagestreefd:

column2: • De student kan drie typen van coördinatiemechanismen (allocatiemechanismen) toelichten en de werking en tekortkomingen van deze mechanismen verklaren.
• De student kan in verschillende situaties verklaren hoe aan de vraagzijde en de aanbodzijde van de markt (op decentraal niveau) beslissingen worden genomen.
• De student kan verklaren hoe de kenmerken van (de vraag naar) zorg de allocatie van gezondheidszorg op een vrije markt beïnvloeden.

• De student kan in verschillende situaties verklaren dat de wijze waarop prijsvorming plaatsvindt afhankelijk is van de markstructuur (marktvormen) en uitleggen welke gevolgen dit heeft voor de marktuitkomst.
• De student kan analyseren welke vormen van markt- en overheidsfalen in de gezondheidszorg relevant zijn.

column2: • Het verhogen van de abstractievermogen door bewijzen te leren construeren met de basis wiskundige concepten zoals de precieze definitie van de limiet, zonder te vervallen in het gebruiken van trucs voor berekeningen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80367,2018,Analysing Contemporary Literature,Engels,Erasmus University College,,['E Edelmann'],,

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

Since the turn of the millennium the democratisation of information- and communication technologies and the proliferation of social media have significantly changed our social interactions and social structures, economies and businesses. This course analyses the digitalisation of everyday life by using case studies of large new media organisations - Wikipedia, Google, Facebook, Youtube and Uber, etc. - structured around themes such as privacy, knowledge, big data, the creative commons and the sharing economy.

It addresses these cases and themes from the perspective of Political Economy and Science & Technology Studies, two very influential critical traditions within the field of New Media Studies. From a political economic perspective we will map, analyse and critically discuss both the organisational ecologies and business models of some of the largest new media organisations. From the perspective of Science & Technology Studies, we will map, analyse and critically discuss the social practices that have shaped, and continue to shape, the interfaces, platforms and applications – and vice versa. In this way, we can pick out and unpick some of today’s most ubiquitous new media organisations, while conceiving them as being part of a larger ‘online ecosystem embedded in a larger socio-cultural and political economic context where [they are] inevitably molded by historical circumstances’, as Jose Van Dijck puts it in The Culture of Connectivity (2013).

This course is structured as a research seminar. This entails that students are required to study the course materials on each case and topic before each session, conduct their own desk- and field research and actively contribute to, and direct, the group discussions.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:

column2: • Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media;
• Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion;
• Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted;
• Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
• Write and present a conference research paper.

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course gives students an enhanced knowledge of statistics as well as a practical training in the use of statistical methods in a real world case project. The case project plays a central role in obtaining a working experience with practical business statistics. The course builds upon the knowledge obtained in the first-year course in statistics that focused on situations with only a single variable of interest (univariate analysis). In practice one is often interested in the relationship between two or more business variables (bivariate or multivariate analysis). Such situations require the use of specific statistical techniques, which are explained in class and in the textbook and which are then practiced in the case project. Following the nature of much empirical research, this applied statistics course covers univariate techniques (e.g., descriptive statistics, interval estimates, and hypothesis tests), bivariate techniques (e.g., t-tests, analysis of variance, contingency tables, and correlation analysis) and multivariate techniques (in particular linear regression methods). These topics are treated in the lectures and workshops in the first half of the course, which covers most of the material of the second half of the textbook. The workshops provide an indispensable preparation for the written exam. The learning process is supported and stimulated by the case project in the second half of the course, where students work in teams of 2-3 in applying statistical methods to analyzing a given data set and in writing a business report. In addition to weekly lectures, weekly PC-lab sessions in the computer labs provide support for the case work and the use of the statistical package R. </body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

This course deals with statistical methods that are of practical importance in everyday business decision making. Students also acquire hands-on experience by applying these methods to a real-life business case.
More specifically, this course teaches students:

column2: • Statistical methods (first part of the course), in particular the statistical analysis of relationships between business variables using techniques such ast-tests, analysis of variance, contingency tables, correlation analysis, simple and multiple linear regression.

• Practical skills (second part of the course), in particular how to translate  practical business problems into the language of statistics, how to use a statistical software (R) to solve a business research question, and how to report the analysis and conclusions in an understandable and valid way.

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82291,2018,Applied Econometrics,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. MJCM Verbeek'],,"Inhoud

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>

<body>This course gives an introduction to the application of econometric techniques to problems in business and management. Focus will be upon the implementation of the linear regression model with non-experimental data. Attention will be paid to estimation, hypothesis testing, specification analysis, misspecification, interpretation, causality, model choice, autocorrelation, heteroskedasticity, and robust inference. A large number of illustrations will be covered and students are expected to complete a small empirical research project. The course will conclude with a short introduction to alternative estimation techniques, like instrumental variables and maximum likelihood.</body>

<meta http-equiv=""content-type"" content=""text/html; charset=utf-8"" /><style type=""text/css"">body { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial } table { font-size: 9pt; font-family: Arial }</style></head>
<body>In the course Applied Econometrics you will be introduced to the linear model in econometrics, including OLS, GLS and IV estimation. Towards the end of the course you should be able:

column2: • to interpret and evaluate estimation results, including adequacy of employed estimators and test procedures;
• to judge the appropriateness of certain assumptions (homoscedasticity, linearity, parameter constancy), and to test them statistically;
• to perform your own empirical study, including model building and selection, misspecification testing, and economic interpretation and forecasting.
